newsitem.title: USA: ValuJet set to return to U.S. skies Monday.
newsitem.headline: ValuJet set to return to U.S. skies Monday.

text.p: ValuJet Inc., the discount carrier that was once a darling on Wall Street but the bane of other airlines, was scheduled to return to the skies Monday for the first time since its grounding three months ago.

With an aggressive weekend marketing campaign, the airline sought to lure passengers back to its no-frills service by offering one-way fares of just $19 for flights between Atlanta and four other U.S. cities, including Washington, D.C.
The authorities grounded the fledgling airline in mid-June -- just over a month after Flight 592 crashed into the Florida Evergrades, killing all 110 passengers and crew on board.

The last time ValuJet planes flew from their Atlanta hub, the carrier had grown in just 2-1/2 years from a tiny startup airline to a regional operation with 320 daily flights to 31 cities and had a payroll of about 4,000 employees.

ValuJet was being relaunched with a fleet of only five DC-9s and staff of 400. After 15-weeks spent in one of the intensive overhauls in U.S. airline history, ValuJet executives have shown nothing but fiery enthusiasm.

"We've done our homework. We have prepared for Game Day. Game Day is here. We're ready for the whistle to blow and we'll be out there doing a great job," ValuJet President Lewis Jordan told reporters after announcing the carrier's return.

The maiden voyage was set to get under way with a departure gate party featuring a jazz band and a news conference with top management that was sure to provide plenty of colourful quotes for the local press.
"We're going to have a nice party out there," said ValuJet spokesman Gregg Kenyon.

At 12:30 p.m. EDT (1630 GMT), a fully booked DC-9 with 113 passengers on board was scheduled to take off for Washington's Dulles airport, carrying a group of VIPs including a U.S. senator and Congressman from Georgia as well as Jordan and ValuJet Chairman Robert Priddy.
The return of ValuJet promised far more fanfare than its birth in October 1993, which transpired without notice.

Rival airlines braced for the onset of ultra-low fares. On Friday, Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines Inc. said it would match the $19 introductory ValuJet fares, which run through Thursday. Kiwi International Air Lines said it also would adopt a similar strategy.

ValuJet came under intense scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) after the May 11 crash. A cause has not yet been determined, but investigators think oxygen generators that were improperly stored in the plane's cargo hold by a subcontractor may have ignited, causing a fire that led to the crash.

After the disaster, FAA inspectors also found widespread maintenance problems at ValuJet, and in mid-June forced the airline to ground its fleet of 51 planes. An intensive 15-week project to overhaul the airline's operations ensued.
The U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) finally declared ValuJet fit to fly again last Thursday. By midday on Friday, the airline had rung up about 7,000 bookings.

Initially, the carrier also will fly to Orlando, Tampa and Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Plans call for the addition of another 12 destinations by Oct. 24, by which time its one-way fares will have risen to $49.
A union for airline flight attendants was still trying to halt ValuJet's rebirth in federal court.
On Friday, the Association of Flight Attendants asked the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington to block the airline's return pending a union appeal to have Jordan and Priddy ousted from management.
The union, which accuses the two men of putting profits ahead of safety during the months preceding the Everglades crash, has launched an appeal of the DOT's approval.
